20101231041044.000|20101231041046.000|TR0|what she's saying here ring at all true to

20101231041048.000|20101231041050.000|TR0|
20101231041050.000|20101231041053.000|TR0|JONATHAN TURLEY, CONSTITUTIONAL ATTORNEY, 
20101231041053.000|20101231041055.000|TR0|GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY:  Well, I 
20101231041055.000|20101231041057.000|TR0|think much of what she says is very hard 
20101231041057.000|20101231041059.000|TR0|to square with the actual language of 
20101231041059.000|20101231041102.000|TR0|these rules.
20101231041102.000|20101231041104.000|TR0|
20101231041104.000|20101231041106.000|TR0|I mean, the -- the rules actually do 
20101231041106.000|20101231041108.000|TR0|prohibit these types of rent arrangements. 
20101231041108.000|20101231041111.000|TR0| You have to go out and get approval for 
20101231041111.000|20101231041113.000|TR0|special arrangements, but they're designed 
20101231041113.000|20101231041115.000|TR0|to -- to discourage this type of thing.
20101231041115.000|20101231041117.000|TR0|
20101231041117.000|20101231041119.000|TR0|She's essentially arguing that she's a 
20101231041119.000|20101231041122.000|TR0|sort of a permanent candidate, that she 
20101231041122.000|20101231041124.000|TR0|can use campaign funds continually, when 
20101231041124.000|20101231041126.000|TR0|you have a system of rules that are 
20101231041126.000|20101231041128.000|TR0|designed to create clear lines, to 
20101231041128.000|20101231041131.000|TR0|separate out personal expenses, but also 
20101231041131.000|20101231041133.000|TR0|to guarantee transparency.  She seems to 
20101231041133.000|20101231041135.000|TR0|be in violation of both of those

20101231041736.000|20101231041738.000|TR0|very hard to make.  Particularly in this 
20101231041738.000|20101231041740.000|TR0|case, I don't see the grounds for it.  It 
20101231041740.000|20101231041743.000|TR0|does occur on some occasions, but I don't 
20101231041743.000|20101231041745.000|TR0|see it on this occasion.
20101231041745.000|20101231041747.000|TR0|

20101231041749.000|20101231041752.000|TR0|these campaign laws are rarely enforced 
20101231041752.000|20101231041754.000|TR0|with jail time, there are separate 
20101231041754.000|20101231041756.000|TR0|provisions about making false statements.  
20101231041756.000|20101231041758.000|TR0|And there's also separate provisions in 
20101231041758.000|20101231041801.000|TR0|terms of conversion of money.

20101231042132.000|20101231042134.000|TR0|COOPER:  Tonight, what happens when a 
20101231042134.000|20101231042137.000|TR0|government agency and one of the biggest 
20101231042137.000|20101231042139.000|TR0|corporations in the world team up to build 
20101231042139.000|20101231042141.000|TR0|a virtual fence?  Well, what happens is 
20101231042141.000|20101231042143.000|TR0|you get a lot of promises, a lot of bills 
20101231042143.000|20101231042146.000|TR0|and, in this case, not a whole lot of 
20101231042146.000|20101231042148.000|TR0|fence.
20101231042148.000|20101231042150.000|TR0|
20101231042150.000|20101231042152.000|TR0|It was supposed to be the big fix in 
20101231042152.000|20101231042155.000|TR0|border security: a virtual fence, a 
20101231042155.000|20101231042157.000|TR0|high-tech system that would all but stop 
20101231042157.000|20101231042159.000|TR0|illegal immigration through surveillance, 
20101231042159.000|20101231042201.000|TR0|ground sensors, radar -- the works.  It 
20101231042201.000|20101231042203.000|TR0|was supposed to be in place and in working 
20101231042203.000|20101231042206.000|TR0|order by now.  The project started under 
20101231042206.000|20101231042208.000|TR0|President Bush back in 2006.
20101231042208.000|20101231042210.000|TR0|
20101231042210.000|20101231042212.000|TR0|But four years and $850 million of 
20101231042212.000|20101231042215.000|TR0|taxpayer money later, the virtual fence is 
20101231042215.000|20101231042217.000|TR0|a virtual disaster, a huge waste of time 
20101231042217.000|20101231042219.000|TR0|and money, tied up in bureaucracy and a 
20101231042219.000|20101231042221.000|TR0|bloated contract between the Department of 
20101231042221.000|20101231042223.000|TR0|Homeland Security and Boeing.  They both, 
20101231042223.000|20101231042226.000|TR0|apparently, bungled the project, and 
20101231042226.000|20101231042228.000|TR0|tonight we're "Keeping Them Honest."
20101231042228.000|20101231042230.000|TR0|
20101231042230.000|20101231042232.000|TR0|Let's take a look at the plan.  Boeing got 
20101231042232.000|20101231042235.000|TR0|the contract to build this virtual fence 
20101231042235.000|20101231042237.000|TR0|back in September of 2006.  Now, according 
20101231042237.000|20101231042239.000|TR0|to a report by the GAO, the Government 
20101231042239.000|20101231042241.000|TR0|Accountability Office, just three months 
20101231042241.000|20101231042244.000|TR0|later the Department of Homeland Security 
20101231042244.000|20101231042246.000|TR0|said by the end of 2009 the entire 
20101231042246.000|20101231042248.000|TR0|northern and southern western borders of 
20101231042248.000|20101231042250.000|TR0|the U.S., a total of 6,000 miles, would be 
20101231042250.000|20101231042252.000|TR0|covered by the fence.
20101231042252.000|20101231042255.000|TR0|
20101231042255.000|20101231042257.000|TR0|Well, late in 2008 that projection was 
20101231042257.000|20101231042259.000|TR0|scaled back, forgetting about the northern 
20101231042259.000|20101231042301.000|TR0|border for a while and the new goal was to 
20101231042301.000|20101231042304.000|TR0|have just 656 miles of the southern border 
20101231042304.000|20101231042306.000|TR0|completed by mid-2011.
20101231042306.000|20101231042308.000|TR0|
20101231042308.000|20101231042310.000|TR0|Well, here's what has actually been 
20101231042310.000|20101231042313.000|TR0|accomplished to date: a handful of cameras 
20101231042313.000|20101231042315.000|TR0|in the Great Lakes area in two small 
20101231042315.000|20101231042317.000|TR0|sections totaling 53 miles.  Fifty-three 
20101231042317.000|20101231042319.000|TR0|miles of virtual fence in Arizona and even 
20101231042319.000|20101231042321.000|TR0|that is said to be not working all that 
20101231042321.000|20101231042324.000|TR0|well.  One problem, the sensors have been 
20101231042324.000|20101231042326.000|TR0|known apparently to have been thrown off 
20101231042326.000|20101231042328.000|TR0|by things like tumbleweeds.
20101231042328.000|20101231042330.000|TR0|

20101231044741.000|20101231044743.000|TR0|ranch, learned to paddle as a young boy.  
20101231044743.000|20101231044745.000|TR0|His father taught him.  He loves the rush 
20101231044745.000|20101231044748.000|TR0|of white water.  In all, he's made more 
20101231044748.000|20101231044750.000|TR0|than 200 drops off cliffs higher than 70 
20101231044750.000|20101231044752.000|TR0|feet.

20101231044805.000|20101231044808.000|TR0|

20101231044841.000|20101231044843.000|TR0|
20101231044843.000|20101231044846.000|TR0|(on camera):  It's amazingly adventurous 
20101231044846.000|20101231044848.000|TR0|stuff.  And I can't help but think, I 
20101231044848.000|20101231044850.000|TR0|mean, what propels you to do this?  The 
20101231044850.000|20101231044852.000|TR0|risk of being hurt and drowning, even 
20101231044852.000|20101231044855.000|TR0|dying.  People's survival instincts sort 
20101231044855.000|20101231044857.000|TR0|of take over yet you do this very 
20101231044857.000|20101231044859.000|TR0|dangerous stuff.  Why?
20101231044859.000|20101231044901.000|TR0|
20101231044901.000|20101231044903.000|TR0|BRADT:  There is no experience like it.  I

20101231044919.000|20101231044921.000|TR0|-- that's my driving force.  I just love 
20101231044921.000|20101231044923.000|TR0|it every aspect about it.
20101231044923.000|20101231044926.000|TR0|
20101231044926.000|20101231044928.000|TR0|GUPTA:  When you are kayaking people say, 
20101231044928.000|20101231044930.000|TR0|"I think that's runnable." I remember that 
20101231044930.000|20101231044932.000|TR0|from the few times I've kayaked.  Now, 
20101231044932.000|20101231044935.000|TR0|what you thought was runnable was a 
20101231044935.000|20101231044937.000|TR0|189-foot waterfall, taller than Niagara 
20101231044937.000|20101231044939.000|TR0|Falls, for context.  How was that 
20101231044939.000|20101231044941.000|TR0|runnable?  At what point did you say that 
20101231044941.000|20101231044944.000|TR0|was going to be OK to do?
20101231044944.000|20101231044946.000|TR0|
20101231044946.000|20101231044948.000|TR0|BRADT:  When -- when I was growing up 
20101231044948.000|20101231044950.000|TR0|kayaking, a very tall waterfall was 70, 
20101231044950.000|20101231044952.000|TR0|80-feet tall.  I ran one 107 feet tall.  
20101231044952.000|20101231044955.000|TR0|That was my biggest one, previous to 
20101231044955.000|20101231044957.000|TR0|Palouse.  And when I looked at Palouse, it 
20101231044957.000|20101231044959.000|TR0|wasn't the height that I was thinking 
20101231044959.000|20101231045001.000|TR0|about; it was the style of waterfall.  I 
20101231045001.000|20101231045004.000|TR0|could look at it, and I could see that it 
20101231045004.000|20101231045006.000|TR0|was possible to run it.
20101231045006.000|20101231045008.000|TR0|
20101231045008.000|20101231045010.000|TR0|And so I think that I ran it more because 
20101231045010.000|20101231045013.000|TR0|I thought I could.  I saw it.  I saw that 
20101231045013.000|20101231045015.000|TR0|I had it within myself to run this 
20101231045015.000|20101231045017.000|TR0|waterfall, to run it successfully and 
20101231045017.000|20101231045019.000|TR0|safely.  And luckily, it went exactly as 
20101231045019.000|20101231045021.000|TR0|we hoped and dreamed that it would.
20101231045021.000|20101231045024.000|TR0|
20101231045024.000|20101231045026.000|TR0|GUPTA:  I think we're looking at some of 
20101231045026.000|20101231045028.000|TR0|the video.  Just now, you're dropping that 
20101231045028.000|20101231045030.000|TR0|much.  From what I understand you went 20 
20101231045030.000|20101231045033.000|TR0|feet down into the water, didn't come up 
20101231045033.000|20101231045035.000|TR0|for 20 seconds.  Do you remember what you 
20101231045035.000|20101231045037.000|TR0|were experiencing?  Obviously, you were 
20101231045037.000|20101231045039.000|TR0|falling, so you were experiencing that, 
20101231045039.000|20101231045041.000|TR0|but how did you not, like, you know, fall 
20101231045041.000|20101231045044.000|TR0|out of the kayak just from the momentum 
20101231045044.000|20101231045046.000|TR0|and the impact?
20101231045046.000|20101231045048.000|TR0|
20101231045048.000|20101231045050.000|TR0|BRADT:  Right.  I -- I invented a system 
20101231045050.000|20101231045053.000|TR0|that literally clamps me into the kayak.  
20101231045053.000|20101231045055.000|TR0|When breaking a record, it's necessary 
20101231045055.000|20101231045057.000|TR0|that you stay in the boat.  If you come 
20101231045057.000|20101231045059.000|TR0|out of the kayak, then it doesn't count.  
20101231045059.000|20101231045102.000|TR0|So it was full commitment for me.
20101231045102.000|20101231045104.000|TR0|
20101231045104.000|20101231045106.000|TR0|I was committed on staying in my boat.  I 
20101231045106.000|20101231045108.000|TR0|had this system that clamped my brace 
20101231045108.000|20101231045110.000|TR0|skirt onto the cockpit of the kayak to 
20101231045110.000|20101231045113.000|TR0|hold me in it. And upon impact I was 
20101231045113.000|20101231045115.000|TR0|pretty dazed.  Through freefall, 
20101231045115.000|20101231045117.000|TR0|everything was going good.  I remember a 
20101231045117.000|20101231045119.000|TR0|very conscious positive thought go through 
20101231045119.000|20101231045122.000|TR0|my head, that this is going great, I'm 
20101231045122.000|20101231045124.000|TR0|exactly where I want to be.
20101231045124.000|20101231045126.000|TR0|
20101231045126.000|20101231045128.000|TR0|GUPTA:  While you're actually falling.
20101231045128.000|20101231045130.000|TR0|
20101231045130.000|20101231045133.000|TR0|BRADT:  Yes, while I'm falling.  My boat 
20101231045133.000|20101231045135.000|TR0|angle is right, which is the most 
20101231045135.000|20101231045137.000|TR0|important thing.
20101231045137.000|20101231045139.000|TR0|
20101231045139.000|20101231045142.000|TR0|GUPTA:  What is that?  Is that just 
20101231045142.000|20101231045144.000|TR0|straight down?
20101231045144.000|20101231045146.000|TR0|
20101231045146.000|20101231045148.000|TR0|BRADT:  Straight down.  It's a lot like 
20101231045148.000|20101231045151.000|TR0|jumping off a bridge or a rock.  You want 
20101231045151.000|20101231045153.000|TR0|to land feet first.  You don't want to 
20101231045153.000|20101231045155.000|TR0|land on your belly or off to one side.  
20101231045155.000|20101231045157.000|TR0|You want to penetrate into the water and 
20101231045157.000|20101231045159.000|TR0|decelerate over as long a period of time 
20101231045159.000|20101231045202.000|TR0|as possible.  That reduces the G-forces 
20101231045202.000|20101231045204.000|TR0|acting upon you, and that's what keeps you 
20101231045204.000|20101231045206.000|TR0|OK.
20101231045206.000|20101231045208.000|TR0|
20101231045208.000|20101231045211.000|TR0|GUPTA:  So instead of just stopping 
20101231045211.000|20101231045213.000|TR0|suddenly you're slowly going into the 
20101231045213.000|20101231045215.000|TR0|water.
20101231045215.000|20101231045217.000|TR0|
20101231045217.000|20101231045220.000|TR0|BRADT:  Exactly.  You want to go as deep 
20101231045220.000|20101231045222.000|TR0|as possible, slow down over as long a 
20101231045222.000|20101231045224.000|TR0|period of time as possible.  It's still a 
20101231045224.000|20101231045226.000|TR0|ferocious impact.  The biggest impact of 
20101231045226.000|20101231045228.000|TR0|my life, and I was completely dazed right 
20101231045228.000|20101231045231.000|TR0|upon impact.
20101231045231.000|20101231045233.000|TR0|
20101231045233.000|20101231045235.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Was that the scariest, one of the 
20101231045235.000|20101231045237.000|TR0|scariest moments?  Or if not, what was?
20101231045237.000|20101231045240.000|TR0|
20101231045240.000|20101231045242.000|TR0|BRADT:  The scariest moment is always when 
20101231045242.000|20101231045244.000|TR0|you're making the decision to do it.  
20101231045244.000|20101231045246.000|TR0|After you've made the decision to run 
20101231045246.000|20101231045248.000|TR0|something, you're getting in your kayak, 
20101231045248.000|20101231045251.000|TR0|you're getting ready to do it, you have to 
20101231045251.000|20101231045253.000|TR0|put that fear aside.  You have to be able 
20101231045253.000|20101231045255.000|TR0|to focus exactly on what you're doing.
20101231045255.000|20101231045257.000|TR0|
20101231045257.000|20101231045300.000|TR0|If you second guess yourself when you're 
20101231045300.000|20101231045302.000|TR0|doing something, if you have an "Oh, crap" 
20101231045302.000|20101231045304.000|TR0|moment right as you're going off the lip 
20101231045304.000|20101231045306.000|TR0|of this waterfall, chances are you're not 
20101231045306.000|20101231045309.000|TR0|going to be able to react to what's going 
20101231045309.000|20101231045311.000|TR0|on right at that specific period of time.
20101231045311.000|20101231045313.000|TR0|
20101231045313.000|20101231045315.000|TR0|So it's necessary to put that fear in a 
20101231045315.000|20101231045317.000|TR0|box, place it to the side.  You know, be 
20101231045317.000|20101231045320.000|TR0|sure you have that fear there when you're 
20101231045320.000|20101231045322.000|TR0|making that decision, because that's what 
20101231045322.000|20101231045324.000|TR0|allows you to make the decision to run it 
20101231045324.000|20101231045326.000|TR0|and be safe, or be safe and walk away from 
20101231045326.000|20101231045329.000|TR0|it and be OK with that.  So fear's an 
20101231045329.000|20101231045331.000|TR0|important part, but you have to push it to 
20101231045331.000|20101231045333.000|TR0|the side when you're running it.
20101231045333.000|20101231045335.000|TR0|
20101231045335.000|20101231045338.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Everything you've just said now, 
20101231045338.000|20101231045340.000|TR0|have there been incidents where you 
20101231045340.000|20101231045342.000|TR0|realized during it now, not before, not 
20101231045342.000|20101231045344.000|TR0|when you're making the decision, but 
20101231045344.000|20101231045346.000|TR0|during the fact that -- the time you're 
20101231045346.000|20101231045349.000|TR0|running something, that it's not going 
20101231045349.000|20101231045351.000|TR0|well and you got scared?
20101231045351.000|20101231045353.000|TR0|

20101231045355.000|20101231045358.000|TR0|periods of time when I was obviously 
20101231045358.000|20101231045400.000|TR0|certainly scared kayaking.  But I try to 
20101231045400.000|20101231045402.000|TR0|keep those to a minimum.
20101231045402.000|20101231045404.000|TR0|
20101231045404.000|20101231045406.000|TR0|GUPTA:  When you think about sort of next 
20101231045406.000|20101231045409.000|TR0|things for you, what if I told you that

20101231045411.000|20101231045413.000|TR0|that can't be a part of your life.  What
